Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Other residents told Capital B they feared potential damage to their homes from the train.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Other residents told Capital B they feared potential damage to their homes from the train.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The proposed condemnation … serves a legitimate public purpose and is necessary for the proper accommodation of the business,” Bond wrote. “The petition of Sandersville Railroad, as amended, is granted.
Document Sources.Source Justification: In April, Capital B reported that Thomas K. Bond, a hearing officer with the Georgia Public Service Commission, approved Sandersville’s request to move forward with condemning properties to construct their railroad spur.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Blaine Smith, a Black man who is one of the heirs of 600 acres that came into their family in the 1920s, said in a statement: “We’re determined to keep fighting against this attempt to take our ancestral land from us.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Blaine Smith, a Black man who is one of the heirs of 600 acres that came into their family in the 1920s

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We want to keep our property whole, so we can pass it down to our children and they can continue to build generational wealth,” Smith added.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Blaine Smith, a Black man who is one of the heirs of 600 acres that came into their family in the 1920s

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Georgia law does not permit a private company to take land through eminent domain unless the land will be put to a public use,” said Bill Maurer, senior attorney for Institute for Justice who represents the landowners.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior attorney for Institute for Justice
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bill Maurer, senior attorney for Institute for Justice who represents the landowners

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Benjamin Tarbutton III, the owner of Sandersville Railroad, has contended this development is expected to create 20 temporary construction jobs, a dozen permanent jobs with an average salary and benefits package of $90,000, and generate over $1.5 million annually for Hancock County.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Benjamin Tarbutton III, the owner of Sandersville Railroad

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The reality is if you’ve ever lived near a train, or you’ve ever ridden on a train or been near a train, it’s not the same as trucks driving by,” Rush said last year. “Even if the train is not going through your property, the fact that a train is near your property — all of the noise pollution, the vibrations of a train … all of that affects your property value, your peace of mind and your home.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: senior staff attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Economic Justice Project
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Jamie Rush, senior staff attorney with the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Economic Justice Project who represents the No Railroad In Our Community Coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I truly hate to have to say this, but if David v. Goliath had been decided by the GA Public Service Commission, they’d have confiscated David’s slingshot and handed it to the Philistines,” Fyre wrote.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Georgia state Rep. Spencer Fyre sent a letter to the commission describing the land acquisition as a “heist attempt”

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The property owners are represented by the nonprofit Institute for Justice, a public interest law firm.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The property owners are represented by the nonprofit Institute for Justice, a public interest law firm.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The railroad project involves constructing a 4.5-mile rail spur to connect the Hanson Quarry, a rock mine owned by Heidelberg Materials, to a main train line along a nearby highway.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The railroad project involves constructing a 4.5-mile rail spur to connect the Hanson Quarry, a rock mine owned by Heidelberg Materials
